@lancefinn78 @DrSamSims @profbeckyallen @CatScutt @ProfCoe @profstig @ProfDanielMuijs @dylanwiliam For my money, outside of behaviour mgmt, I'd focus on consistently excellent curriculum/assessment resources with consistently deep teacher expertise to use/interpret them and consistently excellent PD to support within consistently high quality working conditions.

@lancefinn78 @DrSamSims @profbeckyallen @CatScutt @ProfCoe @profstig @ProfDanielMuijs @dylanwiliam One thing I would say is that I think people sometimes conflate the aims of consistent teacher expertise & consistent excellent outcomes with the more superficial hope that we'll achieve these through visibly consistent teacher actions, focusing carrots/sticks on the latter.

@lancefinn78 @DrSamSims @profbeckyallen @CatScutt It's a very interesting question and I don't personally know a lot of the great evidence that's out there. I wonder if @ProfCoe @profstig @ProfDanielMuijs @dylanwiliam know of any evidence about whether imposing a consistent approach to teaching/pedagogy is valuable?

@lancefinn78 @DrSamSims @profbeckyallen @CatScutt I think there's evidence around consistency in behaviour management, consistent support _from_ leaders, possibly consistent or at least aligned curricula/assessment + the related materials, but I don't think I'm personally aware of evidence about imposing consistent pedagogy?

Work context was found to be very important: social support from colleagues, shared vision, organisational justice, support for autonomy, supportive climate, support from leaders, positive relationships with parents, positive teacher-student relationships & mentors for ECTs https://t.co/UlfuexDn8Z

"... feeling satisfied with the working conditions, feeling competent, or feeling committed to the school) were positively related to at least some aspects of TWB [...]  feeling stressed or burdened, pressured or overworked) were negatively correlated" https://t.co/hytpipRMd6

When disaggregating to country type, however, then within OECD-only countries, this relationship is only significant in schools with more educated teachers and tends to be the strongest effect when teachers have more influence in decision-making around curriculum and pedagogy

Third paper, by @TLuschei and Dong Wook Jeong, explores PISA 2015 data and finds that within the 68 countries they looked at, the greater the school's reported of teacher responsibility for school decision-making the greater the school's results in maths and reading. https://t.co/Fi5DGeDb1j

Key aspects included scheduling/protecting time, appointing a Lesson Study (LS) co-ordinator, embedding into the school's vision & goal statements, leaders protecting time/priorities for it and monitoring progress, leaders becoming knowledgeable about LS + focusing on motivation https://t.co/INoLf7QFaw

8. I'm thinking how public attitudes have shifted to be so much more inclusive in many countries, despite the recent minority upsurge in transphobia particularly virulent here in the UK. But we now know better than thinking this is permanent progress.

7. But I'm also thinking how much better things have got, despite all of that. How many out gay, lesbian, bi, trans, non-binary, and other wonderfully queer sexuality and gender non conforming people are finding greater peace and less persecution than generations before.

6. I'm thinking of all of us who are working for LGBT+ equality and inclusion facing increasing hostility on social media and being accused of being "groomers" and "anti woman" - a thoroughly horrible throwback to the '80s.

5.I'm thinking about every trans person in the UK suffering from an exceptional rising tide of transphobia - endless, deeply harmful allegations that they're mentally unwell, dangerous to women and children and to gay men and lesbian women. https://t.co/vdQ1WbjEOV
4. I'm thinking of the disproportionate number of LGBT+ youth who end up as homeless here in the UK https://t.co/WXoTPUyj60
3. I'm thinking about the *7 in 10* young LGBT+ young people who experience suicidal thoughts and feelings (compared to 3 in 10 for non-LGBT+) https://t.co/SjiFHMJ9nu

Not a bad set of results but I would have *definitely* had Ireland üáÆüá™ there instead of Azerbaijan or Australia

üá®üáø Czech Republic: We Are Domi ‚Äì Lights Off: what. a. banger! I can forgive the /slightly/ pitchy high notes - I loved this, especially after some super-dodgy rehearsals. Amazing staging! 9/10.
üá∏üá™ Sweden: Cornelia Jakobs ‚Äì Hold Me Closer: chills, she nailed it. Everything came together - just wonderful. Even the simplest of staging. 9/10

üáßüá™ Belgium: J√©r√©mie Makiese ‚Äì Miss You: got a pitchy at the end there, but generally a solid performance of a song that is nice enough. Feel this artist's skills were underutilised here. 6/10
üá≤üá™ Montenegro: Vladana ‚Äì Breathe: wearing her own portable satellite dish, Vladana delivered way better than in rehearsals, but it's just not a great song. 6/10
üáµüá± Poland: Ochman ‚Äì River: strongest vocalist by far, so far tonight. Maybe just a little nervous and introverted, but when this is in the final, this could just be incredible. 9/10

üá∑üá¥ Romania: WRS ‚Äì Ll√°mame: Nonsense, catchy lyrics, muscled dancers in crop-tops, random flamenco outfit on the lead. With better singing and fewer backing dancer mistakes, could have been stronger. But for now, 6/10.
üá™üá™ Estonia: Stefan ‚Äì Hope: he *worked* that stage, extra points for the sheer number of winks at camera. Catchy, fun song that got everyone bopping along. Great stuff. 8/10

üá≤üá∞ North Macedonia: Andrea ‚Äì Circles: another song that peaks way too soon. First chorus way too big and left her nowhere to go but louder and screamier. Shame, I liked the pre-competition edit of this. 6/10.

üáÆüá™ Ireland: Brooke ‚Äì That‚Äôs Rich: Sassy, pink and sparkly. One of the better stage presences, making up for the lack of power in the vocals. Liked this more than I expected. Needs to be in the final. 8/10.
üá®üáæ Cyprus: Andromache ‚Äì Ela: fun song, sadly let down by very weak, out of tune vocals. Frustrating, this could have been good if she'd nailed it, I think. 5/10

üá¶üá∫ Australia: Sheldon Riley ‚Äì Not The Same: stunning staging, lighting and amazing outfit, but the song is just waaaaay too repetitive. WE GET IT, YOU'RE NOT THE SAME, NOOOOOO. Enough already. 5/10

üá∏üá≤ San Marino: Achille Lauro ‚Äì Stripper: certainly rocked that transparent, rhinestoned, sleeveless onesie there, didn't he. Sexy, dirty, silliness on a bucking bronco. Great talent? No, but fun. 7/10.

üá≤üáπ Malta: Emma Muscat ‚Äì I Am What I Am: beautiful girl, beautiful voice, slightly nervy performance though better than some rehearsals. Not sure why they left her dancers so late to join in. Wanted to love it more. 6/10
üá¨üá™ Georgia: Circus Mircus ‚Äì Lock Me In: weird, repetitive song and some Clockwork Orange meets Yellow Submarine graphics. Think I'd have enjoyed more on mute. 2/10.
üá¶üáø Azerbaijan: Nadir Rustamli ‚Äì Fade To Black: Jason Momoa crossed with Justin Timberlake sings second tier song with bad high-school musical staging. 4/10.

üá∑üá∏ Serbia: Konstrakta ‚Äì In Corpore Sano: absolutely as weird as expected but with extra psychedelic background. Somehow expected more of a 'moment' but hey, we're all clapping and singing 'bitistrava' now, aren't we. 7/10
üáÆüá± Israel: Michael Ben David ‚Äì I.M: nah. Way too much speak-singing for me, despite the camp fun. Needed more melody and had lacklustre staging: 4/10
üá´üáÆ Finland: The Rasmus ‚Äì Jezebel: solid performance, high energy opener. Found myself oddly annoyed by the poor scansion. 7/10
So, let's brace for Eurovision Semi Final 2! Live tweeting this with gusto as I can't live tweet the final on Saturday as I'll be travelling home.

18. üá®üáø Czech Republic: We Are Domi ‚Äì Lights Off: at one point, my favourite track - the studio version is brilliant Electronic Dance, but so far the live vocals just haven't been living up to it. Nonetheless, a banger. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2

17. üá∏üá™ Sweden: Cornelia Jakobs ‚Äì Hold Me Closer: from Eurovision's powerhouse comes another hit. This one is just easy to love, huge potential, even a winner. My only qualm is slightly unreliable vocals and whether the staging is interesting enough. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2

16. üáßüá™ Belgium: J√©r√©mie Makiese ‚Äì Miss You: something very funky about this track, though I've seen hits and misses in pre-performances in terms of the vocals. It's a bit different, hard to predict this one.
15. üá≤üá™ Montenegro: Vladana ‚Äì Breathe: this ballady-type song never quite gets going and then suddenly she's yelling. A miss, for me. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2
14. üáµüá± Poland: Ochman ‚Äì River: first of tonight's major contenders. Amazing singer, big song, absolutely *weird* on-stage dancers which detract, but this is a cracker. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2

13. üá∑üá¥ Romania: WRS ‚Äì Ll√°mame: with your eyes closed, this is Ibiza Chill territory. With your eyes open this is a high camp gay club performance. Confusing but sort of fun. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2
12. üá™üá™ Estonia: Stefan ‚Äì Hope: Eastern Europe meets Wild West. Catchy and fun song, bit of cheese, should do well. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2
11. üá≤üá∞ North Macedonia: Andrea ‚Äì Circles: there's something very lovely about this song, but it peaks too soon and this talented artist could have achieved more. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2

10. üáÆüá™ Ireland: Brooke ‚Äì That‚Äôs Rich: nice uptempo cheesy pop. Brooke looked like 'normal lass up on stage doing karaoke' in early performances, hope Ireland ups the ante for this big show. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2
9. üá®üáæ Cyprus: Andromache ‚Äì Ela: absolutely standard Eurovision fare, perfectly pleasant, and that's about it. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2

8. üá¶üá∫ Australia: Sheldon Riley ‚Äì Not The Same: apparently a popular entry this year but I find everything after the first 60s to be boringly exactly the same, ironically. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2
7. üá∏üá≤ San Marino: Achille Lauro ‚Äì Stripper: small country attempts to repeat Italy's win last year with similar-ish but nowhere near as good song. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2
6. üá≤üáπ Malta: Emma Muscat ‚Äì I Am What I Am: absolute paint-by-numbers pop-hit territory but with a lovely singer, instantly memorable hook, hard to dislike. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2
5. üá¨üá™ Georgia: Circus Mircus ‚Äì Lock Me In: also an appropriate title, as somebody should have locked 'em away - why this is on a Eurovision stage I have no idea. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2
4. üá¶üáø Azerbaijan: Nadir Rustamli ‚Äì Fade To Black: An appropriate title as I've already forgotten it having listened 5 minutes ago. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2

3. üá∑üá∏ Serbia: Konstrakta ‚Äì In Corpore Sano: a discussion about Megan Markle's skin, with some random latin lyrics and on-stage handwashing. Eurovision-tastic weirdness, oddly catchy. Might do well. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2

2. üáÆüá± Israel: Michael Ben David ‚Äì I.M: as my partner says 'not quite Dana International, is it'. Camp, with an extra service of camp on the side. Maybe it's supposed to be deep reflective lyrics, but all we get is shallow. Meh. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2

1. üá´üáÆ Finland: The Rasmus ‚Äì Jezebel - some general rock fun in yellow and black. From rehearsals, looks like a slick number with good vocals, from a band known to some already. #Eurovision #Eurosemi2
Here we go folks, here's a few pre-thoughts about #Eurovision #EuroSemi2 - all 18 artists on tonight. üßµ

üá¶üá≤ Armenia: Rosa Linn ‚Äì Snap: nailed the vocals there, quality. A quality that was absolutely not mirrored by the cheap toilet-paper staging. Shame. But this is an ear-worm, nonetheless. 7/10 #Eurovision #Eurovision2022 #EuroSemi1

üá≥üá¥ Norway: Subwoolfer ‚Äì Give That Wolf A Banana: strangely underwhelming after some kick-ass rehearsals and pre-shows. Swallowed by the stage. Maybe nervous, but it's a top-contender that fell short for me. 7/10
üá¨üá∑ Greece: Amanda Georgiadi Tenfjord ‚Äì Die Together: ooh, the drama! Lovely staging. She didn't *quite* nail the vocals like in rehearsal, but this is a contender with a bit of tidying. 8/10

üáÆüá∏ Iceland: Systur ‚Äì Me√∞ H√¶kkandi S√≥l: this is the song for which the word 'cute' was invented. Lovely lighting. Who cares about the weird outfits? My boyfriend wants to learn Icelandic because of this song. But... just 6/10 for me. #Eurovision #Eurovision2022 #EuroSemi1

üá¶üáπ Austria: LUM!X feat. Pia Maria ‚Äì Halo: I urge you to listen to the studio recording... as let's face it she needed a bit of auto-tune there. Fun bit of EDM for the evening, but the quality wasn't there. 6/10 #Eurovision #Eurovision2022 #EuroSemi1

üá©üá∞ Denmark: REDDI ‚Äì The Show: #GirlPower - fun, and better than I'd expected. Shame about the poor vocal volume mixing, but everyone loves a key-change, hoorah! Still... just not that strong overall. 6/10 #Eurovision #Eurovision2022 #EuroSemi1

üá≠üá∑ Croatia: Mia Dim≈°iƒá ‚Äì Guilty Pleasure: she nailed this, vocally. The outfit and staging are weird and I still finding the composition too empty. But I found myself enjoying it tonight. Oh, and I love the newly non-English final verse 7/10 #Eurovision #Eurovision2022 #EuroSemi1

üáµüáπ Portugal: MARO ‚Äì Saudade, Saudade: such a beautiful song, and kudos to the audience for the phone light, candle-lit background. Keep listening to this, it's a grower. 7/10 #Eurovision #Eurovision2022 #EuroSemi1

üá≤üá© Moldova: Zdob ≈üi Zdub & Fra»õii Advahov ‚Äì Trenule»õul. I mean, look, it's a shit song. And yet it's very Eurovision and I was kind of bopping along, as was the crowd. Almost embarrassed to score this a 5/10.

üá≥üá± Netherlands: S10 ‚Äì De Diepte: weaker vocals than before, but stronger staging & an emotive performance. With a bit more confidence, this is a big track for the final. #Eurovision #Eurovision2022 #EuroSemi1 8/10
Oops should have said, 7/10.

üáßüá¨ Bulgaria: Intelligent Music Project ‚Äì Intention: 80s rock. This was much more fun than their video and their rehearsals. Have to admit I kind of enjoyed this slick performance, surprisingly. #Eurovision #Eurovision2022 #EuroSemi1

üá∫üá¶ Ukraine: Kalush Orchestra ‚Äì Stefania: what a banger! Don't know about you, but I just find it moving watching them up there. Maybe a little messier than I'd hoped, but this is the first winning contender of the night. 8/10 #Eurovision #Eurovision2022
EXCITING - HERE COMES UKRAINE! üá∫üá¶

üá∏üáÆ Slovenia: LPS ‚Äì Disko: Somehow the charm of the original video is faded. Screams 'EuroFiller', unfortunately. If you're still with us, the songs get much stronger, I promise! 4/10 #Eurovision #Eurovision2022
Switzerland: Marius Bear ‚Äì Boys Do Cry. To quote the lyric. "Oh-oh-oh-oh-oh-oh-ee-oh-oh". Exactly as boring as anticipated. 2/10. #Eurovision #Eurovision2022

Lithuania: Monika Liu ‚Äì Sentimentai. Go Monika! Chanson-esque delights, had us all eating out of the palm of her hand. Beautiful vocals too. But, but, but... the song is fundamentally not quite enough of a banger. #Eurovision #Eurovision2022
Latvia: Citi Zƒìni ‚Äì Eat Your Salad. God I hate this song. 1/10. #Eurovision
OKAY, here we go with live. Ronela certainly went for it... but the vocals were very pitchy. Too much time swinging her hair and too little singing. 5 out of 10.

17. Armenia: Hat tip @nixywork for the description 'think Mumford and Sons, but just mum and no sons'. Cute track, video was great but the performance rehearsal clips looked rather flat... but should scrape through.
16. Norway: absolute Eurovision heaven - singers in wolf costumes, a song about bananas, catchy song, great dance moves. It'll definitely go through.

15. Greece: I was sceptical about the video from this track, but there is something catchy about this track (despite having an odd suicide pact vibe?) and the rehearsals suggest a powerful performance.
14. Iceland: another soft and gentle 'grower' which my partner really loves but I just don't think it'll catch people sufficiently on the first listen.
13. Austria: absolute banger of an electronic dance music track, but not quite enough Eurovision wow factor and their rehearsals suggest weak vocals. Likely to go through nonetheless.
12. Denmark: a strange sort of ballad-becomes-pop-becomes-rock track that is almost catchy but just never quite delivers. I think this is 50-50 to go through.

11. Croatia: this is *almost* a brilliant song, but the production was really weak and it's just a bit... empty. It's a shame, the artist is cute, the final repetition finally delivers some punch. If only it had gained momentum sooner. Still likely to go through.

10. Portugal: this is a melancholy, dreamy song that's a huge grower over time. It's some real quality and I worry that it won't make enough impact on the first listen - it didn't for me - but this is one I'll be listening to for years. Hopefully progressing.
9. Moldova: ethno-pop-cheese about trains, or something. The video was kind of ridiculous fun, the rehearsal looks much less good. Unlikely to go through.
8. Netherlands: a strong showing, catchy song with an instantly memorable and repeatable hook. Almost certain to go through.
7. Bulgaria: Old men playing rock. Meh. Unlikely to progress.

6. Ukraine: absolute belter of a track, proper ethno-bop, I loved this even before seeing the staging and this is a *strong* favourite (if the betting odds are to be believed) to win the whole contest. Guaranteed to progress.
5. Slovenia: overly earnest school band doing cheesy music in front of a big disco ball. Pretty uninspiring stuff.
4. Switzerland: deep, meaningful, intensely boring.
3. Lithuania: classy, disco-tastic number. The singer is kind of fabulous, the song is catchy, but doesn't really go anywhere. Despite that, I think it may well go through.

2. Latvia: a Eurovision cheese-fest with some fairly shocking lyrics - so shocking that they have been forcibly removed and replace with images in the background. I'm *really* not a fan of this; also unlikely to progress, I think.

1. Albania: a big song that has seen controversy about the costumes being used and where social media criticism seemed to have rattled their artist. I'm not a huge fan, but it could progress over (in my view) better songs if it goes well tonight.
Here's a run-down of my person views of the 17. I've heard their tracks, watched their official videos and seen snippets of their rehearsals. My predictions are likely to be fairly wrong!

This is the first of two semi-finals, with 10 of the 17 progressing to the grand final on Saturday, where they will be joined by 10 from Semi final 2 plus the 'big five' who automatically progress: UK, Spain, Germany, France & Italy.

@Transgendertrd @me2intheuk @SexMattersOrg I do not yet have confidence that the guidance from either of the two organisations mentioned does indeed command this support, so I could not, in all good conscience, recommend it.

@Transgendertrd @me2intheuk @SexMattersOrg Fundamentally, I return to the point that guidance on how to support and include a group of pupils with specific need or characteristic needs also to command the support of the majority of people with that need or characteristic.

@Transgendertrd @me2intheuk @SexMattersOrg Of course, I fully agree that we need to protect the rights and needs of all pupils. And that should be done in a way which commands the support of all of the particular groups that we seek to include.

@me2intheuk @SexMattersOrg @Transgendertrd The government does. And advice on how to safely support & include a minority group should be something that the majority of that group endorse. Hence my scepticism about the two sources you mention which, as I understand it, do not command support from most trans people.

@john_stephens67 Yes, and I think I've seen similar approaches in the USA using cherry picked stories of teachers who commit crimes to argue for home schooling.
The remedy, I think, is to seek representative answers and be cautious of people brandishing collections of stories to undermine your trust in minorities and build your sense of fear.
And that leads to dehumanising things like "let's export them to Rwanda" or "let's make it harder for them to transition" or "let's ban face coverings".

You hear them use such unrepresentative stories to assert things like "yes let's be sympathetic to them but it's just too dangerous to have them in Britain/in schools/in women's loos and if you say otherwise then you hate Britain/children/women" and so on.

There are groups of people who disproportionately share and scaremonger stories of crimes of specific minorities, e.g. migrants, gays, Muslims, trans people, etc. Such fearmongers cherry pick crimes to infer we must be afraid of these minorities.

Caveats: (11/11) https://t.co/psjFbcIQ16
"While gender transition can mitigate these challenges, the health and well-being of transgender people can be harmed by stigmatizing and discriminatory treatment." (10/11)

"Transgender individuals, particularly those who cannot access treatment for gender dysphoria or who encounter unsupportive social environments, are more likely [...] to experience health challenges such as depression, anxiety, suicidality and minority stress" (9/11)

Success factors include "adequate preparation and mental health support prior to treatment, proper follow-up care from knowledgeable providers, consistent family and social support, and high-quality surgical outcomes (when surgery is involved)" (8/11)

"Regrets following gender transition are extremely rare and have become even rarer as both surgical techniques and social support have improved. Pooling data from numerous studies demonstrates a regret rate ranging from .3 percent to 3.8 percent." (7/11)
"The positive impact of gender transition on transgender well-being has grown considerably in recent years, as both surgical techniques and social support have improved." (6/11)
Outcomes include "improved quality of life, greater relationship satisfaction, higher self-esteem and confidence, and reductions in anxiety, depression, suicidality, and substance use." (5/11)
"The scholarly literature makes clear that gender transition is effective in treating gender dysphoria and can significantly improve the well-being of transgender individuals." (4/11)

Overall, "we found a robust international consensus" that "gender transition, including medical treatments such as hormone therapy and surgeries, improves the overall well-being of transgender individuals" (3/11)

"We conducted a systematic literature review of all peer-reviewed articles published in English between 1991 and June 2017" and "We identified 55 studies that consist of primary research on this topic" (2/11)

Anyway, I know there‚Äôs passion and deep-felt different views on this. You may read this and feel riled up and want to attack me or pile on. I‚Äôm just trying to explain what I perceive and why it cuts deep. But I will keep trying to listen and understand views different to mine.

And this scenario feels very painfully close to what happened in the 90s and why I get so angry at how trans people are being treated right now. This zero sum game claim: to protect women and children we can‚Äôt also accept what LGBTQ+ people tell us.

And then they say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very sympathetic to gay men who come out but we need to demand certificates and a rigorous proof process before they‚Äôre allowed to be or act gay, to protect women and children‚Äù.

Imagine that gay men then said ‚Äúbut you‚Äôre demonising us‚Äù and the response was ‚Äúhow dare you tell women that their concerns aren‚Äôt real, you‚Äôre anti feminist‚Äù, and ‚Äúhow dare you harm children‚Äù and ‚Äúthere‚Äôs no genetic sign you‚Äôre gay anyway‚Äù.

Imagine a group started a campaign that said ‚Äústraight men are pretending to be gay to befriend and attack women‚Äù and ‚Äúchildren are being misled that they‚Äôre gay‚Äù and then ‚Äúwe should demand medical certificates before someone can say they‚Äôre gay‚Äù

Or‚Ä¶ as the pressure recedes to put on an act for fear of violence and bullying, allowing more of us to let friends and family in to our reality and understand who we really are, we‚Äôre finally understanding who truly is LGBTQ+ https://t.co/qRnU6So38h

Finally, thanks from me to all the panellists, to our excellent Chair @GarethConyard, in the hot-seat just 2 weeks after starting at TDT, and to everyone who came along and contributed. The recording will be available soon and we'd love to continue this conversation.

@Stillteaches @GarethConyard I think there is a danger if it's not done well. I think I'd like teachers feeling supported and developed all the time, not steered/guided/monitored all the time. And that distinction is really key for this to feel valuable & valued by teachers, TA's and other staff.

.@GarethConyard thanks the panellists, @Concettina_J1 @chadda_amit @DamienRobertsIP and for those asking questions including @Stillteaches @adamboxer1 on Twitter and all those in the room. This is something TDT really cares about improving for teachers and schools #TDTconf

.@Concettina_J1: in another @TeacherDevTrust network school they separated different meetings into different types of conversations: 1) goal setting, 2) planning CPD, 3) line manager support, 4) reviewing. Again: there's no 1 perfect structure #TDTconf

.@Concettina_J1 comes back to practical detail about how to separate out evaluation from coaching: e.g. one person who does performance related pay or career progression evaluation discussions; but a separate learning partner or coach who meets regularly for development #TDTconf
Some audience questions: how can we find time to train staff to do this well and to have sufficiently frequent conversations? #TDTconf

.@GarethConyard: the faster that you can give specific positive praise, as soon as possible after it happened, the better. The same is true for feedback for improvement - so regular and quick is important #TDTconf

.@chadda_amit: we can't forget that there needs to be specific space and time made for rapid, well-structured praise, there needs to be celebration of what works well: people value specific and thoughtful recognition #TDTconf
.@chadda_amit: part of the positive outcome from effective performance management is giving staff more sense of ownership over both their professional learning and their career development #TDTconf
RT @shirleydrummon5: Superb input from the panel @TeacherDevTrust Thank you all- really helpful to assist in improving and developing our p‚Ä¶
.@Concettina_J1: this is partly why there's no one perfect system - what works in a small primary may look very different from a large secondary, for example #TDTconf
.@Concettina_J1: having worked in small schools, it's really tricky to get people together, hard to pair people with enough knowledge of each other's roles. #TDTconf

.@GarethConyard: performance management is too often focused on individual discussions and doesn't necessarily bring in enough focus on team discussions about 'how we improve/achieve' together. #TDTconf

.@Concettina_J1 picks some examples from @TeacherDevTrust network schools - e.g. a school that focused PM targets on process, not product, i.e. the discussion was around efforts made toward improvement, not around judging/comparing outcomes #TDTconf

.@Concettina_J1: it's fundamental that you mustn't just have the 'judgement/evaluation' side of performance management without the coaching and development side - that makes it feel much more 'done to' #TDTconf
.@DamienRobertsIP: giving staff space to be involved in the process, having some agency in their own targets, some focus on what they want to achieve - that's key. #TDTconf

.@GarethConyard puts @adamboxer1's point to the panel "Performance management is often done *to* teachers and we don't think enough about their side of things and what works and what doesn't from that angle" #TDTconf

.@DamienRobertsIP: transparency of the process is really important. If the process and the records are all secret, it's hard to trust it - again, something that software (like @SchooliP) can help with #TDTconf

.@chadda_amit: don't try and make a change to your performance management all by yourself. You need to involve colleagues about what works, what's not liked, what could be better. Consultation + open conversations are key to creating a more collectively valued new system #TDTconf
https://t.co/sp4rclzzIT
https://t.co/qjoxIDotDu
https://t.co/cxfnGRwrSk
https://t.co/GlHkj87OVI
https://t.co/M8n7ljkZNg
Here's some key links related to todays discussions: https://t.co/YOjbghOIio
.@chadda_amit: it's important to make sure that record-keeping is kept light and focus on having really powerful conversations #TDTconf
.@Concettina_J1: the key is to separate out accountability and support; one person is assessing practice but the more regular conversation is with a trusted and valued coach. #TDTconf
.@GarethConyard poses @Stillteaches' question from twitter https://t.co/1RgeckyQki
@Stillteaches @TeacherDevTrust @DamienRobertsIP @chadda_amit @Concettina_J1 @GarethConyard Just posed your question to the panel! Will tweet the answers.

.@Concettina_J1 encourages us to consider not only individual appraisal but also team appraisal that encourages staff to think of themselves as part of a collective - joint responsibility to develop performance. #TDTconf

.@Concettina_J1 reflects that developmental-focused PM can strike some leaders  as 'fluffy' but there can be a robust focus on teachers bringing and discussing formative assessment around pupils' progress but this can stay developmental and high trust #TDTconf

.@Concettina_J1 discusses the idea that we need to encourage a 'learning orientation' and not a 'performance orientation' if we want appraisal to lead to improvement in complex domains such as teaching #TDTconf

.@Concettina_J1 sketches out the separate processes: one person who has regular appraisal discussions and another who is a coach with plenty of ongoing dialogue and lots of chance to tweak practice. #TDTconf
.@Concettina_J1 draws a parallel to assessment feedback to pupils where they will focus on grades given and less on developmental comments - having the two together is hard to make work #TDTconf

.@Concettina_J1 quotes the @CIPD and @CenterforEBMgt review that identifies that appraisal relationships need to focus _either_ on judgement _or_ development - it's almost impossible for one person to do both. #TDTconf
.@Concettina_J1: there isn't a perfect or correct way to do performance management, but it's about finding an approach that works well. #TDTconf

@adamboxer1 @TeacherDevTrust @DamienRobertsIP @chadda_amit @Concettina_J1 @GarethConyard Yes, it's far too often done _to_ teachers. Concettina was a teacher until December, Amit is just about to go back as a school leader next month and they and all of us at TDT interview and speak to hundreds of teachers (and TA's and other staff) every year about this #TDTconf
.@chadda_amit: we need to build the skills of line managers, middle leaders and senior leaders, empowering them to have powerful, non judgemental conversations. #TDTconf

.@chadda_amit: annual PM conversations should be 'no surprises' - these meetings are the not the place to discover bad news but to summarise what happened in the year, the key is ongoing discussions and feedback #TDTconf

.@chadda_amit: when line managers are confident in the way they conduct conversations and regular dialogue, it builds trust, keeps the focus on development, reduces the fear and increases the impact and helpful accountability elements on performance management #TDTconf
.@chadda_amit: schools that to PM well integrate it very much into every day work, regular meetings and discussions; it's not just a one-off annual thing. #TDTconf
.@chadda_amit reflects the language is key to set this up as a process that feels supportive, the words we use matter #TDTconf

.@chadda_amit quotes @RobinsonViviane to note that we don't create trust before we do the main work in schools but we create trust _through_ the hard work and conversations we have in schools #TDTconf
.@chadda_amit quotes the TDT paper, A Culture of Improvement - https://t.co/lgUTSwbfGY - reflecting on the sorts of conditions that support both teacher improvement and retention.

.@chadda_amit: at @TeacherDevTrust we get to spend a long time finding out how staff and leaders feel about appraisal and performance management; I'd like to think particularly about the conditions that make appraisal work well. #TDTconf
.@GarethConyard: key points in that input - how conversations + processes connect, how this links to school improvement. #TDTconf
.@DamienRobertsIP: we've tried to reimagine performance management in the way we've developed @SchooliP #TDTconf

.@DamienRobertsIP: we're reaching very worrying levels of teachers leaving the profession and workload is a commonly cited issue, so appraisal must be done with, not to, and must not be burdensome #TDTconf
.@DamienRobertsIP: the level of training and support for teachers is the make or break for a successful system - it needs to be received well by staff #TDTconf
.@DamienRobertsIP takes us through key elements of the DfE model approach; touchpoints should be little and often, the process should be simple and accessible. #TDTConf
.@DamienRobertsIP notes that the DfE model approach here focuses on the developmental side of things: https://t.co/uHlu8ykhYP #TDTconf

.@DamienRobertsIP: appraisal can be tickbox exercises that can be dismissed with little productive evidence gathered, few constructive conversations. Staff can see them as judgemental, even when grading is now frowned upon. #TDTconf
.@GarethConyard: when things go wrong, performance management can be seen as a deficit model, about preparing for capability, rather than a positive system #TDTconf

3 favourites of the night:
- AJ & Kai's quickstep
- Rose & Gio's waltz
- Rhys & Nancy's samba
#Strictly #scd2021

So my totals for each couple (out of 20)
- Rose & Gio: 19
- John & Johannes: 18
- AJ & Kai + Rhys & Nancy: both 17
#Strictly #scd2021

Rose & Gio's Argentine Tango: very beautiful, delicate. I felt myself wanting a little more power/drive throughout, but it was so confidently and musically danced, great fluidity and precision. ‚ùæ #Strictly #scd2021
This was nearly an 8, but I just thought the performance levels were so strong, it deserved more. But definitely not perfect enough to be a 10.

John & Johannes's Jive: loved the sparkly outfits ü§©. Superb rhythm, great kicks, great energy generally. I'd have liked him to keep he knees a bit more connected together and I'd have liked more lightness/bounce in his rock-step. ‚ùæ #Strictly #scd2021
@CarlyWaterman21 https://t.co/OzQoCZr76m
9s and 10s! Gosh, I'm very out of kilter on this one...

I do agree with Shirley's point, she did track her feet well. Listening to the judges I'm wondering if a) they've been swept up in the moment or b) I'm missing something. Though I *really* do love AJ. #Strictly #scd2021

AJ/Kai: I love her... but this didn't have the quality for me. Some nice footwork but I didn't see the settling of her weight or the elasticity of her back this needs. There wasn't the resistance in the feet or connection. Nice musicality but less confident. ‚ùº #Strictly #scd2021
Oh my goodness, AJ and Kai have been given Rumba for the semi?! Harsh! Let's see...
@mrs_darl And deservedly so! Amazing.

The quality from these couples! Already reflecting that if this was @dragraceukbbc then RuPaul would already be considering taking all 4 through to the final. I'd love that here too! #Strictly #scd2021

Motsi again making a really great technical point, the changes of rhythm were great. Unlike most couples, rather than just going slow and stopping, they smoothed the action out, it 'moved like honey'. #Strictly #scd2021

Rhys/Nancy's Samba: very impressive. Despite sometimes rushing the music, Rhys had some of the most impressive core bounce action of any celebrity on the show. Some really strong basic steps, clean legs and kept strong posture - no rounded shoulders. ‚ùæ #Strictly #scd2021
What a great set of first dances! Glad that they're showing some VTs to give the couples time to change outfits. @bbcstrictly #Strictly #scd2021

Simple things made me really happy: she didn't just put her head in the right position, she shaped her body right from her centre, without distorting her legs and feet. There was such lightness which shows she's really holding her own, not relying on Gio. #Strictly #scd2021

Rose/Gio's Waltz: oh my goodness, the quality, I was just in heaven watching this. Incredibly use of her legs and feet, her frame was beautiful, her shaping, her contra-body motion, the musicality was magical. It was just extraordinary. ‚ùø!! #Strictly #scd2021
Leading up to Rose & Gio. It's hard to keep remembering that Rose is deaf, considering the quality of dancing she consistently produces. What a star. Here comes the dance...

I generally find couple's choice routines harder to mark - not my area of specialism as it's not ballroom/latin. Quite reasonably, everyone in the studio was really moved. I think the significance of this routine was more than the score though. #Strictly #scd2021

John & Johannes: this was lovely and I enjoyed watching - rather moving. A tender performance. I think it wasn't quite as lyrical/flowing or connected as I'd have liked and I'm wasn't completely convinced by the choreography at times. ‚ùΩ  #Strictly #scd2021
All the emotional VTs coming out for the semifinal! That was really moving from John there. ‚ù§‚Äçüåà #Strictly #scd2021
That was, without doubt, one of the dances of the series. #Strictly #scd2021

Next, AJ & Kai: stunning dress/look. If I'd been in the studio this would be a standing ovation from me. Lightness and energy, featherlike but strong frame, superb footwork, stellar performance. LOVED this. ‚ùø!

9s from the judges! I wonder if this looked a bit better in the studio? Then again judges have all seen earlier auditions so they have a sense of how to mentally rank each dance. Or I'm being harsh :) #Strictly #scd2021
Nice point by Motsi there about Rhys's use of the standing leg - i.e. how much he pushes off the leg he's standing on which gives more power. It was indeed much better. #Strictly #scd2021

First up: Rhy's posture looks better in terms of head position, but his right elbow was too far back which distorted his shoulder. Not sure his footwork was that clear and occasionally turned in feet. Nice routine though and great rhythm as usual. ‚ùΩ
Finally going to be tweeting along live to @bbcstrictly #Strictly this week.

AJ & Kai: up until that last lift it looked really amazing, just occasionally slightly uncertain but then they'd absolutely packed it with really great content. I feel it is one of those that they'd repeat in the final and smash 10s across the board. In the end, 8Ô∏è‚É£.

Dan & Nadiya: not bad. Dan is very square in his body and leads a bit much with his arms which looks a bit heavy or unsteady. He did lead pretty well through lifts, the legs and feet looked reasonably strong, but I found it lacking in intensity, a bit flat. 7Ô∏è‚É£

Rose & Giovanni: *beautiful*. Light, accurate, incredible lift, effortlessly musical, brilliant ballroom footwork and shaping, amazing finish of every shape and arm placement. And she just makes you smile - real theatrical performance. üîü

Rhys & Nancy: this was great! Amazing precision, great energy & lifts. The one thing I was missing was Rhys rolling his shoulders back and down and just projecting slightly more power in his upper body. But this was a superb dance: intense, intricate, contained, atmospheric. 9Ô∏è‚É£

In case you're interested, I think that The Extended Mind by @anniemurphypaul feels like one of those books with real significance for the education sector; it's covering new and important ground. I'm tweeting ideas as I read along. https://t.co/HTGOMvB5zQ
Overall, this chapter adds to the previous one to suggest that tuning our built and natural environment can be beneficial for how we think, live and learn.
Interestingly, there are signs that allowing people to personalise their desks and make them "homey" increases engagement and productivity and reduce stress. https://t.co/GdiryL3UpL
Murphy Paul quotes research suggesting that staff social interaction may decrease on moving to an open plan office.
Reducing environmental cognitive load increases creativity. https://t.co/7pJ04aHa8P

.@anniemurphypaul quotes Fabrice Parmentier: our attention is subject to involuntary capture by sudden or surprising noises. That is, the brain has evolved to be distractible, especially by speech. https://t.co/lbkPHc7ioa

A significant argument made here is that the move in civilisation to having walled off spaces was crucial to reduced the cognitive load of socializing to give space to think about other things. https://t.co/JwqTKhDiDq
Chapter 5 is about Thinking with Built Spaces. https://t.co/lyMUkCZxSM
Overall this chapter was, for me, more interesting than particularly compelling.
It may be that one mechanism is that nature can trigger our sensation of awe which stimulates curiosity and open mindedness. https://t.co/LxQWp68NRR
... and delaying gratification. https://t.co/1xhw2Re7Bz
There's some studies suggesting a link between viewing nature and improved learning... https://t.co/samNBFi9SC
Murphy Paul goes on to look at how the colours and fractal patterns of nature seem associated with natural relaxation and even pain reduction.
This seems to be associated with all sorts of things including improved working memory & improved concentration.
The key idea is that our brains appeared to be particularly attuned to natural settings. https://t.co/Lc5P8OqKjI
Onward! Chapter 4 is about Thinking with Natural Spaces. https://t.co/LX1FJRVdDC

Overall, my view is that chapter 3 holds significant promise for pedagogy and developing teachers' expertise.
And, elsewhere, teachers who employ gesture as part of classes improve pupils' learning https://t.co/eiAVmdtQAe
In another study, teachers were prompted to become much more alert and sensitive to the meaning of pupils' https://t.co/0rNdIwLCuj

There's some tantalising ideas suggested here too. Girls' use of gesture is associated with spatial thinking skills and another study in the book found that girls especially benefited when prompted to gesture in learning. https://t.co/o0Cz90V9LL

One of the key mechanisms for gesture seems to be that it primes the brain's auditory cortex for meaning, so that subsequent words that are congruent are more salient and likely to be remembered. https://t.co/iY0FeIsH7U
Murphy Paul goes on to note that it's not just novices who learn using gesture; there are studies showing that groups of experts use gesture substantially when learning and discuss ideas together.
Gesture seems particularly important to observe during learning of older children and adults too. It may seemingly signal both progress in learning and readiness to learn. https://t.co/dVDbVUfAvU

This seems extremely important to learning and vocabulary acquisition. Level of exposure to gesture is associated with vocabulary learning: words gaps seem connected to "gesture gaps". https://t.co/yZQT6Ieq0b

Fascinatingly, we often both "speak" and "hear" meaning first through our gesture, followed by words. The gesture can be the more reliable indicator of thinking. Gesture also increases fluency and memorisation. https://t.co/aKJBWEbl49
.@anniemurphypaul notes that gesture is a form of "dual coding"; it reinforces rather than distracts working memory from spoken word. It also adds meaning. https://t.co/QPB6uc73Kv
This chapter focuses on the significance in communication and thought of physical gesture. https://t.co/8XdXrJcUBK

Overall, I found Chapter 2 encouraging of the idea of more movement - anything from gentle exercise while thinking/working to designing activities to support learning, to code memory not just with words but also embodied cognition.
There is also evidence that finding movements to associate with metaphors can simulate our thinking about the metaphor‚Äôs meaning. https://t.co/gGF4gz5euD

‚Ä¶ while this example is about acting out or simulating a complex process to bring ‚Äúself referential‚Äù movement into learning - certainly something I used in my own science teaching. https://t.co/Jb6S7NLV66

This linking of memory, experience and novel movement can be harnessed to support learning, something that is of course familiar to most teachers! This is example is about experiencing a phenomenon‚Ä¶ https://t.co/n7f6RHRWsf

Murphy Paul notes that experts within a domain more effectively both notice and remember observations of actions they have mastered - ie we preferentially attend to and remember info that we connect to our own movement. https://t.co/X8fEuedQzo

She also notes that we may be more likely to remember things when they are associated with movement, citing actors‚Äô improved memory of lines once they are associated with movements around a stage. https://t.co/VmLuWnp7ex
Our tendency to fidget while thinking may be a way that we self regulate to maintain attention. https://t.co/iJLiWRkOKK

In Chapter 2, @anniemurphypaul explores the importance of movement, starting by challenging the assumption that our best thinking is done while sitting still. We‚Äôve evolved to think while moving. https://t.co/ijnUyxRZm2
@GarethConyard https://t.co/vSh0HZR4Gv

Key reflections from Chapter 1: developing interoception is, plausibly, a very valuable strategy for developing expertise in high stress domains - I‚Äôd suggest that teaching may just such a domain. It may also help develop pupils‚Äô resilience and emotion intelligence.

She also recounts how Elizabeth Stanley found that cognitively resilient and expert practitioners are mindful - they pay attention earlier to more subtle interoceptive signs, shuttling attention back and forth between internal bodily sensation and what was happening outside. https://t.co/wnTUkNknUf
Murphy Paul recounts an experiment that suggests that cognitive resilience in the face of stress is also correlated with interoceptive sensitivity. https://t.co/LR6dfGQZag
@JamesTheo *exactly *
Also worth noting that interoception is central to our ‚Äúfeeling‚Äù of emotions. One of my other favourite writers about the brain, @LFeldmanBarrett, writes more here: https://t.co/DDbwSTFU5E
Murphy Paul notes that greater interoceptive awareness has been shown to improve decision making, reduce bias, improve outcomes. https://t.co/G8reiDI4YV

Here‚Äôs more on the absolutely crucial concept of interoception. It‚Äôs more than ‚Äúlistening to your gut‚Äù it‚Äôs learning to even hear it and interpret it, not just your gut but a whole variety of internal sensations. https://t.co/0UjdqP0LCh

Part of Embodied Cognition is the highly neglected sense, not sight, sound, smell etc. but *interoception*, the sending of internal bodily sensation. It‚Äôs so neglected that it comes up as a spelling error on most devices but it‚Äôs absolutely crucial in developing any expertise.
@Emma_Turner75 @anniemurphypaul @olicav @MrGoodwin23 Wonderful!

@MPye1980 @bennewmark It depends also on the complexity/interdependency of the task, from my reading. Did you see the other papers in the thread that explore this more?
@bennewmark Absolutely! It assumes that the only reason that performance isn't being achieved is either not being applied or is being prioritised elsewhere.

Once again these papers fundamentally reinforce the idea that your performance management system *must* have a strong link to ongoing professional learning if you don't want to actively reduce teachers' performance.

Secondly, it's important to consider separately proximal v distal goals - e.g. 'how my class does in this current topic' v 'how my class does at the end of GCSE' and how different combinations may be better for novices v experienced teachers.

What would this mean for school performance management? Firstly, recognising that performance goals alone may only be suitable when sufficient understanding, skill, perceptive expertise, self-efficacy, resources are all in place.

Interestingly, Masuda et al also found that, initially, increasing task challenge was positively associated with performance, but this plateaued and then ultimately fell off. They hypothesise a link with working memory limits. https://t.co/pTNFVUTGRm

There's some more nuanced findings from another paper (again HT @ryandal) by Masuda (@EADABusiness) et al where they find that a combination of learning *and* performance goals can also be effective. https://t.co/cM9pd9PNeQ https://t.co/JGqlzlsN4L
This paper correlates nicely with the @CIPD @CenterforEBMgt review of performance management https://t.co/ybeWTJ2LWb
Importantly, the learning goals stimulate increased self-efficacy which correlates with greater likelihood of 'information search' https://t.co/adJq79OZ2W

But if 'doing more of the same' or redoubling of existing efforts won't cut it, then use of a performance goal instead of a learning goal is likely to hinder the achievement of better results - it makes teachers less likely to focus on problem-solving & learning.

A performance goal such as 'achieve these class results' is only helpful for a teacher if they already have all the perceptive understanding of students' challenges, the skill and resources to meet them. It encourages them to prioritise attention/time/effort to this goal.

Thanks to @ryandal for putting me onto this brilliant paper by @GerardSeijts et al. This absolutely nails why teacher performance goals aren't helpful if teachers don't *already* have all the skills/resources to achieve the performance. https://t.co/WRR5t2J0BA https://t.co/TESrAm67zm
@ryandal @bennewmark @MrsBallAP @johntomsett Seems to be online here: https://t.co/WRR5t2J0BA

We strongly believe in strengthening our profession and collegiality. Our courses will be designed to enable easy progression into @CharteredColl chartered routes. https://t.co/xu3NnEE4gB

Local Delivery Partners will support and guide participants as they progress through the core materials, engaging them in discussion in online forums, getting to know them in advance of virtual and in-person sessions that they run.

We've been championing great professional learning, whether through our work with DfE on CPD Standards, the Early Career Framework and the new NPQ Frameworks, or through our core work on membership and training for schools.

We'll be offering the three new specialist NPQs (Leading Teacher Development, Leading Teaching (& Curriculum), Leading Behaviour & Culture) as well as the Senior, Headteacher and Executive Leadership level qualifications through our network of Delivery Partners

The paper appears to be freely available here: https://t.co/aNDCcvyMmm

You really can't underestimate the importance of this. Meeting quality is directly associated with morale and job satisfaction - good meetings have positive effects and bad ones have negative effects. https://t.co/Li9cw0DbTJ
They point out the multiple roles and responsibilities of the meeting Chair - a highly skilled role. https://t.co/sh5NaeoxJm

They note that a good meeting can helpfully include a discussion of difficult areas but complaints that signal that problems are fixed/unmalleable begin 'complaining cycles' that are highly problematic. https://t.co/UY1MUyshFf
And then go on with a helpful check-list of factors that promote good meetings. https://t.co/LxsyKNYcOg
They begin by summarising some key findings from three key areas of meeting science. https://t.co/eHZg9nMzym

This is a great paper by Joseph E. Mroz and colleagues on the science of workplace meetings. (short thread üßµ) - this area is absolutely core to @TeacherDevTrust's view on effective school leadership. https://t.co/QrlRNdyglQ
